metadata.title: Mechanizing Cotton Production in the American South: The Tractor, 1915-1960

relevance.topic: Mechanization of cotton production in the American South
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of mechanization, particularly the introduction of tractors, on labor displacement in the cotton industry in the American South.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on the American South, particularly the cotton-producing regions.

dependent_variables.displaced: Sharecroppers' farms declined by more than 90% between 1930 and 1959.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: The displacement of sharecroppers and laborers due to mechanization.

text_fragments: Sharecropping, upon which much of postbellum cotton production was based, was literally wiped out; sharecroppers' farms declined by more than 90% between 1930 and 1959.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the gradual adoption of tractors and the resulting displacement of labor, particularly sharecroppers, in the cotton industry.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The study covers the period of the Great Depression and post-World War II economic changes.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses the role of federal farm programs, price supports, and subsidized credit in facilitating mechanization.

outcomes.main_findings: The introduction of tractors and cotton pickers led to significant labor displacement, particularly among sharecroppers, and transformed the cotton industry into a modern agricultural sector.
outcomes.conclusions: Mechanization, particularly the adoption of tractors, was a key factor in the transformation of the cotton industry, leading to increased efficiency but also significant labor displacement.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The mechanization of cotton production contributed to the decline of sharecropping and the migration of displaced workers to urban areas.
